member.name: F:App.Modules.All.Shared.Attributes.Enums.SourceType.AppSetting
member.summary:
Directly within the code base.
Only Appropriate for for relative configuration settings that are neither deployment identifiers (eg: name of AAD Tenancy, or DNS of System) or worse, client secrets/passwords.

member.name: F:App.Modules.All.Shared.Attributes.Enums.SourceType.AppSettingsViaDeploymentPipeline
member.summary:
Not included in the Code base directly, the AppSetting is injected into the web.config when the Resources are Built up.
Appropriate for VSTS/Build Pipeline injected identifiers such as AAD Tenancy name, DNS domain names, etc. that must not end up in the code repository (all Repositories are basically public and have zero security) but are ok to be known to the development and other team members via the build pipeline interface which will divulge them.
Important: this setting cannot be enforced. It's up to the deployer to see the source -- and not ignore it because it's maybe faster/more convenient to.

member.name: F:App.Modules.All.Shared.Attributes.Enums.SourceType.KeyVault
member.summary:
Reserved for deployment and integration secrets/passwords.
The keyvault can be locked down to access by only the service (and build pipeline) ensuring that secrets are not accessible by team members, since they don't need to know them.
Potentially also for vSTS/Build pipeline injected identifiers, although this probably makes it a little more unwieldy, and certainly slower at startup.

member.name: P:App.Modules.All.Shared.Models.Entities.TenantFKRecordStatedTimestampedCustomIdEntityBase`1.TenantFK
member.summary:
Gets or sets the FK of the Tenancy this mutable model belongs to.
When referenced from within the Core Module's DbContext the TenantFK is logically enforced by the database (normalized), whereas from other DbContexts it is not. The Logic behind this choice stems from the understanding that a Business Model (eg: Foo) has no need to Navigate to a Tenant to which the Business Model belongs. It's actually a different Domain Context (System). The above logic is actually enforced in EF's natural constraint that a Model belong to only one DbContext (one Bounded Context). The advantage is natural Domain Separation. In the same way as we trust external IdP Services to manage Users. THe consideration is that Application logic is required to ensure TenantId is applied at the Application Logic tier, as it is not enforced at the database. TenantFK is not required on anything else but the TenantProperties entity, and Users in order to know which Tenant a user is allowed to be a member of.

member.name: T:App.Modules.All.Shared.Models.IConfigurationComponentStatus
member.summary:
Contract for an in-memory, singleton, entity, summarizing whether a service have been configured correctly or not (or are still unknown).
Basically, applications need at the very least a database service (which is technically a remote service). And will also need a cache service, key vault service, email service, etc. before it can be used in production.
Each service that relies on configuration in turn references a singleton instance of a configuration object (an named instance of this object).
A service summarizes them and shows them up on a dashboard of some kind.

member.summary:
Contract for Models (eg System models or DTO Message models) that use an Integer for the index.
In practice, integers Ids should be reserved for Immutable Reference data. Anything other Model -- eg Mutable Reference data or domain model - that can be edited from two different systems requires a Guid to ensure collision does not occur. (ie, prefer the use of for most models in a system).

summary.para: Any mutable model should have a Guid Id as opposed to an integer Id. Hence
Resource data have because an item can be disabled (eg a list of countries may have current trade sanctions against North Korea or other country).
Resource data should offer a *default* order hint (0 being undefined) that may differ from the natural alphabetic ordering of the Text label. Hence .
It also has because the data is mutable, and therefore is unique to each Tenant.

member.summary:
The target Record's Identifier value (almost always a Guid).
If the target record's key is a Guid, then you can reference that directly. But if the target has a composite key, or is an int, that is not feasible. In which case, you have to convert it to something else (a Type 5 Guid constructed from the SHA1 hash of a string -- eg a Json of they values).
They can't class as they are different classes (Type 5 versus 4 for random versus etc...)
Note that TenantFK information is not addressed at this level/in this contract.

member.name: T:App.Modules.All.Shared.Models.IHasTenantFK
member.summary:
Contract applied to Models that are specific to a single Tenant.
Most models - including the ones within Core - are specific to a single Tenant.

member.name: P:App.Modules.All.Shared.Models.IHasTenantFK.TenantFK
member.summary:
Gets or sets the FK of the Tenancy this mutable model belongs to.
When referenced from within the Core Module's DbContext the TenantFK is logically enforced by the database (normalized), whereas from other DbContexts it is not. The Logic behind this choice stems from the understanding that a Business Model (eg: Foo) has no need to Navigate to a Tenant to which the Business Model belongs. It's actually a different Domain Context (System). The above logic is actually enforced in EF's natural constraint that a Model belong to only one DbContext (one Bounded Context). The advantage is natural Domain Separation. In the same way as we trust external IdP Services to manage Users. THe consideration is that Application logic is required to ensure TenantId is applied at the Application Logic tier, as it is not enforced at the database. TenantFK is not required on anything else but the TenantProperties entity, and Users in order to know which Tenant a user is allowed to be a member of.

member.name: P:App.Modules.Core.Shared.Models.Messages.API.V0100.NotificationDto.TenantFK
member.summary:
Gets or sets the FK of the Tenancy this mutable model belongs to.
When referenced from within the Core Module's DbContext the TenantFK is logically enforced by the database (normalized), whereas from other DbContexts it is not. The Logic behind this choice stems from the understanding that a Business Model (eg: Foo) has no need to Navigate to a Tenant to which the Business Model belongs. It's actually a different Domain Context (System). The above logic is actually enforced in EF's natural constraint that a Model belong to only one DbContext (one Bounded Context). The advantage is natural Domain Separation. In the same way as we trust external IdP Services to manage Users. THe consideration is that Application logic is required to ensure TenantId is applied at the Application Logic tier, as it is not enforced at the database. TenantFK is not required on anything else but the TenantProperties entity, and Users in order to know which Tenant a user is allowed to be a member of.

member.name: T:App.Modules.Core.Shared.Models.Messages.ConfigurationStatusComponentBase
member.summary:
An in-memory, singleton, entity summarizing whether a service have been configured correctly or not (or are still unknown).
Basically, applications need at the very least a database service (which is technically a remote service). And will also need a cache service, key vault service, email service, etc. before it can be used in production.
Each service that relies on configuration in turn references a singleton instance of a configuration object (an named instance of this object).
A service summarizes them and shows them up on a dashboard of some kind.

member.name: P:App.Modules.Core.Shared.Models.Entities.AuditRecord.RecordIdentifier
member.summary:
The target Record's Identifier value (almost always a Guid).
If the target record's key is a Guid, then you can reference that directly. But if the target has a composite key, or is an int, that is not feasible. In which case, you have to convert it to something else (a Type 5 Guid constructed from the SHA1 hash of a string -- eg a Json of they values).
They can't class as they are different classes (Type 5 versus 4 for random versus etc...)
Note that TenantFK information is not addressed at this level/in this contract.

member.name: T:App.Modules.Core.Shared.Models.Entities.PrincipalLogin
member.summary: A Principal can login from several foreign IdPs (FB, Google, ML, thisApp...). The user will be known by the remote Idp under a different login (eg: foo@google.com) as well as a unique reference id for the user (often a guid, but can be anything, hence string storage is best). When an IdP sends back the response, it has to be correlated back to a System Principal. That's done via this object.

member.name: P:App.Modules.Core.Shared.Models.Entities.TenantClaim.TenantFK
member.summary:
Gets or sets the FK of the Tenancy this mutable model belongs to.
When referenced from within the Core Module's DbContext the TenantFK is logically enforced by the database (normalized), whereas from other DbContexts it is not. The Logic behind this choice stems from the understanding that a Business Model (eg: Foo) has no need to Navigate to a Tenant to which the Business Model belongs. It's actually a different Domain Context (System). The above logic is actually enforced in EF's natural constraint that a Model belong to only one DbContext (one Bounded Context). The advantage is natural Domain Separation. In the same way as we trust external IdP Services to manage Users. THe consideration is that Application logic is required to ensure TenantId is applied at the Application Logic tier, as it is not enforced at the database. TenantFK is not required on anything else but the TenantProperties entity, and Users in order to know which Tenant a user is allowed to be a member of.
